title_html: Solving Road Congestion
html:

Solving Road Congestion

Maybe it’s solving itself.

Leor Grebler
Apr 20

I’m curious what road congestion in North America will look like in 15 years.

The biggest reducers will likely be remote work and autonomous vehicles.

With people able to work more flexibly from anywhere, commuting to an office seems a bit anachronistic unless you can benefit from one on one with fellow coworkers. Flexible schedules also mean less of a need to get to an office by 9 AM, spreading out start times and when people need to be on the road.

Autonomous driving, however, has the ability to significantly reduce congestion in a number of ways:

  • Lower cost of “ride share” apps will start to compete with traditional vehicle ownership on a mileage basis
  • Fewer congestion causing accidents by autonomous drivers
  • Less congestion causing behaviour by autonomous drivers
  • Collaborative routing to reduce congestion and distribute traffic
  • Shoulder or narrower driving — something that would cause accidents in human drivers

I don’t think that infrastructure can significantly relieve congestion to the same extent over the same period. It might take 15 years so build a highway to see its benefits. The effect of these two areas on congestion will be one of the surprise benefits of AI.

  • Self Driving Cars
  • Traffic
  • Autonomous Cars
  • Autonomous Vehicles
  • Future

title: Solving Road Congestion
content_html:
Solving Road Congestion

Maybe it’s solving itself.

Leor Grebler
Apr 20

I’m curious what road congestion in North America will look like in 15 years.

The biggest reducers will likely be remote work and autonomous vehicles.

With people able to work more flexibly from anywhere, commuting to an office seems a bit anachronistic unless you can benefit from one on one with fellow coworkers. Flexible schedules also mean less of a need to get to an office by 9 AM, spreading out start times and when people need to be on the road.

Autonomous driving, however, has the ability to significantly reduce congestion in a number of ways:

  • Lower cost of “ride share” apps will start to compete with traditional vehicle ownership on a mileage basis
  • Fewer congestion causing accidents by autonomous drivers
  • Less congestion causing behaviour by autonomous drivers
  • Collaborative routing to reduce congestion and distribute traffic
  • Shoulder or narrower driving — something that would cause accidents in human drivers

I don’t think that infrastructure can significantly relieve congestion to the same extent over the same period. It might take 15 years so build a highway to see its benefits. The effect of these two areas on congestion will be one of the surprise benefits of AI.
